column1: besides that, the sisters plagued her in all sorts of ways, and laughed at her
in the evening when she was tired, she had no bed to lie down on, but was made to lie by the hearth among the ashes; and as this, of course, made her always dusty and dirty, they called her ashputtel
ashputtelâs two sisters were asked to come; so they called her up, and said, ânow, comb our hair, brush our shoes, and tie our sashes for us, for we are going to dance at the kingâs feast

â then she did as she was told; but when all was done she could not help crying, for she thought to herself, she should so have liked to have gone with them to the ball; and at last she begged her mother very hard to let her go

âyou, ashputtel ! â said she; âyou who have nothing to wear, no clothes at all, and who cannot even danceâyou want to go to the ball ? and when she kept on begging, she said at last, to get rid of her, âi will throw this dishful of peas into the ash-heap, and if in two hoursâ time you have picked them all out, you shall go to the feast too
then ashputtel brought the dish to her mother, overjoyed at the thought that now she should go to the ball
but the mother said, âno, no ! you slut, you have no clothes, and cannot dance; you shall not go
â and when ashputtel begged very hard to go, she said, âif you can in one hourâs time pick two of those dishes of peas out of the ashes, you shall go too
and then ashputtel took the dishes to her mother, rejoicing to think that she should now go to the ball
but her mother said, âit is all of no use, you cannot go; you have no clothes, and cannot dance, and you would only put us to shameâ: and off she went with her two daughters to the ball

now when all were gone, and nobody left at home, ashputtel went sorrowfully and sat down under the hazel-tree, and cried out: âshake, shake, hazel-tree, gold and silver over me ! â then her friend the bird flew out of the tree, and brought a gold and silver dress for her, and slippers of spangled silk; and she put them on, and followed her sisters to the feast

now when all were gone, and nobody left at home, ashputtel went sorrowfully and sat down under the hazel-tree, and cried out: âshake, shake, hazel-tree, gold and silver over me ! â then her friend the bird flew out of the tree, and brought a gold and silver dress for her, and slippers of spangled silk; and she put them on, and followed her sisters to the feast
but she slipped away from him, unawares, and ran off towards home; and as the prince followed her, she jumped up into the pigeon-house and shut the door

but when they had broken open the door they found no one within; and as they came back into the house, ashputtel was lying, as she always did, in her dirty frock by the ashes, and her dim little lamp was burning in the chimney

the next day when the feast was again held, and her father, mother, and sisters were gone, ashputtel went to the hazel-tree, and said: âshake, shake, hazel-tree, gold and silver over me ! â and the bird came and brought a still finer dress than the one she had worn the day before

the next day when the feast was again held, and her father, mother, and sisters were gone, ashputtel went to the hazel-tree, and said: âshake, shake, hazel-tree, gold and silver over me ! â and the bird came and brought a still finer dress than the one she had worn the day before
â the father thought to himself, âcan it be ashputtel ? â so he had an axe brought; and they cut down the tree, but found no one upon it

and when they came back into the kitchen, there lay ashputtel among the ashes; for she had slipped down on the other side of the tree, and carried her beautiful clothes back to the bird at the hazel-tree, and then put on her little grey frock

the third day, when her father and mother and sisters were gone, she went again into the garden, and said: âshake, shake, hazel-tree, gold and silver over me ! â then her kind friend the bird brought a dress still finer than the former one, and slippers which were all of gold: so that when she came to the feast no one knew what to say, for wonder at her beauty: and the kingâs son danced with nobody but her; and when anyone else asked her to dance, he said, âthis lady is my partner, sir

the third day, when her father and mother and sisters were gone, she went again into the garden, and said: âshake, shake, hazel-tree, gold and silver over me ! â then her kind friend the bird brought a dress still finer than the former one, and slippers which were all of gold: so that when she came to the feast no one knew what to say, for wonder at her beauty: and the kingâs son danced with nobody but her; and when anyone else asked her to dance, he said, âthis lady is my partner, sir
the prince took the shoe, and went the next day to the king his father, and said, âi will take for my wife the lady that this golden slipper fits
â then both the sisters were overjoyed to hear it; for they had beautiful feet, and had no doubt that they could wear the golden slipper
the eldest went first into the room where the slipper was, and wanted to try it on, and the mother stood by
then the mother gave her a knife, and said, ânever mind, cut it off; when you are queen you will not care about toes; you will not want to walk

but on their way home they had to pass by the hazel-tree that ashputtel had planted; and on the branch sat a little dove singing: âback again ! back again ! look to the shoe ! the shoe is too small, and not made for you ! prince ! prince ! look again for thy bride, for sheâs not the true one that sits by thy side

but on their way home they had to pass by the hazel-tree that ashputtel had planted; and on the branch sat a little dove singing: âback again ! back again ! look to the shoe ! the shoe is too small, and not made for you ! prince ! prince ! look again for thy bride, for sheâs not the true one that sits by thy side
â then the prince got down and looked at her foot; and he saw, by the blood that streamed from it, what a trick she had played him
so he turned his horse round, and brought the false bride back to her home, and said, âthis is not the right bride; let the other sister try and put on the slipper
but her mother squeezed it in till the blood came, and took her to the kingâs son: and he set her as his bride by his side on his horse, and rode away with her

but when they came to the hazel-tree the little dove sat there still, and sang: âback again ! back again ! look to the shoe ! the shoe is too small, and not made for you ! prince ! prince ! look again for thy bride, for sheâs not the true one that sits by thy side

âthis is not the true bride,â said he to the father; âhave you no other daughters ? â âno,â said he; âthere is only a little dirty ashputtel here, the child of my first wife; i am sure she cannot be the bride
â the prince told him to send her
but the mother said, âno, no, she is much too dirty; she will not dare to show herself
â however, the prince would have her come; and she first washed her face and hands, and then went in and curtsied to him, and he reached her the golden slipper
â but the mother and both the sisters were frightened, and turned pale with anger as he took ashputtel on his horse, and rode away with her

and when they came to the hazel-tree, the white dove sang: âhome ! home ! look at the shoe ! princess ! the shoe was made for you ! prince ! prince ! take home thy bride, for she is the true one that sits by thy side ! â and when the dove had done its song, it came flying, and perched upon her right shoulder, and so went home with her
